urn:contentItem:5WK8-1F01-JBVR-3021-00000-00Three Ontario wildfire evacuees facing assault charges in Saskatchewan2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNATIONALThree Ontario wildfire evacuees facing assault charges in SaskatchewanOntario evacuees face assault charges in ReginaThe Canadian Press

Regina police say three men and one woman who were brought to Saskatchewan as wildfire evacuees from northern Ontario are facing assault charges.

Police say the charges stem from separate calls to the University of Regina campus, where evacuees are being housed.

They say a fight broke out on Friday in one of the residence towers and a 24-year-old man was allegedly assaulted by two men.

Edward Dawson Wade Keeper, who is 19, and Darian Moose, who is 22, are charged with assault causing bodily harm.

Early Saturday, campus security was alerted to the sounds of fighting coming from one of the rooms, where police discovered a 28-year-old woman with serious injuries.

A 29-year-old man who was staying in the same living area has been charged with aggravated assault and disobeying a court order, and police say they are withholding his name to protect the identity of the woman.

Late Sunday, officers responded to the residences and arrested a 27-year-old woman after another woman the same age alleged she was assaulted.

Chelsey Strang appeared in provincial court Monday morning charged with common assault as well as breach of undertaking.

Last week, Saskatchewan agreed to welcome around 2,000 residents from the Pikangikum First Nation in Ontario as a forest fire raged nearby.

Saskatchewan officials said for the most part, those staying in Regina have respectful, although they said there have been some incidents and some minor damage to bedding and flooring at the university.

"Interactions, fighting, those kind of things you would normally see under close environment with people that are under significant duress. So it's been scrapping, fighting, that kind of stuff," said Duane McKay of the Saskatchewan Public Safety Agency.

Games and activities have been set up for the families including outdoor sports activities, swimming and a room with TVs and colouring books.

McKay said the damage costs will be covered by the federal government.

Planning has begun to return the evacuees home.

McKay said storms that passed through the province over the weekend are expected to provide much needed rain to help fight forest fires.

People planning on catching a seaplane today may be grounded for awhile.

Harbour Air has cancelled any flights heading to Comox, Nanaimo, Richmond or Vancouver due to poor visibility from the wildfire smoke.

"The problem is the Strait between the Mainland and the Island," said Randy Wright, president of Harbour Air. "The visibility is below minimum."

#HAflightstatus [10:50 am Aug 21] Several routes are now being affected by delays and cancellations due to poor visibility from forest fire smoke. Updates will continue to be posted as available. Flight status info is online at https://t.co/kTxVyrfLsw— Harbour Air Seaplanes (@HarbourAirLtd) August 21, 2018

Flights going to Sechelt and Whistler are still running, but Harbour Air is monitoring the situation hour by hour to see if more schedule changes will be made.

"We have to work around it," Wright said, "You never know when there will be a puff of wind to blow it all away."

On Monday alone, Harbour Air had to cancel 70 flights.

To keep up to date on flight cancellations, you can check out Harbour Air's Twitter page.

The Victoria International Airport is also experiencing schedule changes.

"We are experience some delays with inbound flights from airports, or connecting through airports that are being impacted by the smoke," said Ken Gallant, director of operations and safety. "Delays range from minutes up to an hour."

To keep an eye on incoming flights, you can visit victoriaairport.com/arrivals

urn:contentItem:5T38-1YY1-F105-6113-00000-00Smokey skies will linger awhile in Maple Ridge2018-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSSmokey skies will linger awhile in Maple RidgePhil Melnychuk

Metro Vancouver is stuck in the doldrums with no wind in sight and forest fire smoke continuing to choke the region.

Maple Ridge's air quality health index hit a high of nine, on a scale of 10 being the worst, as of Monday morning. Pitt Meadows had the same reading, according to Metro Vancouver's air map.

Metro Vancouver said on Sunday that it's continuing its air quality advisory for Metro Vancouver and the Fraser Valley because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter due to smoke from wildfires burning. Elevated levels of fine particulate matter are expected to persist until there is a change in fire or weather conditions.

Metro Vancouver offers the following tips:

Avoid roads with heavy vehicle traffic and areas with wood smoke.

Stay cool and drink plenty of water.

Continue to manage medical conditions such as asthma, chronic respiratory disease and heart failure. If symptoms continue to be bothersome, seek medical attention.

Maintaining good overall health is a good way to reduce health risks resulting from short-term exposure to air pollution.

For people with chronic underlying medical conditions:

Stay in a cool, air-conditioned environment and reduce indoor sources of pollution such as smoking and vacuuming.

Run an air cleaner. Some room air cleaners, such as HEPA filters, can help reduce indoor particulate levels provided they are the right size for your home and filters are changed regularly.

Consider taking shelter in air-conditioned buildings which have large indoor volumes and limited entry of outdoor air.

urn:contentItem:52WR-V721-DYRH-B00H-00000-00Canadian Natural Resources Limited Provides an Update on Alberta Forest Fires2011-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisCanadian Natural Resources Limited Provides an Update on Alberta Forest Fires

CALGARY, ALBERTA--(Marketwire - May 17, 2011) - A number of forest fires continue to burn in North CentralAlberta and in the oil sands region near Fort McMurray, which are impacting Canadian Natural Resources Limited's ("Canadian Natural" or the "Company") (TSX:CNQ) (NYSE:CNQ) operations and current production. None of the events have resulted in any injuries to Canadian Natural's employees or its contractor's employees.

Canadian Natural is responding to a forest fire near its Horizon Oil Sands site. The forest fire encroached to approximately 150 metres from its Chelsea Lodge, one of three staff camps on site. A fire barrier has been put in place and to date has been successful in diverting the forest fire away from the lodge and the balance of the Horizon Oil Sands site. Approximately 1,300 camp residents and personnel have been evacuated from both the Chelsea Lodge and the Calumet Lodge. In addition, all non-essential, non-operational personnel remain off the Horizon site and will return to site once the forest fire situation has passed. The Company's fire fighting personnel on site are monitoring the fire's progress and are taking steps to minimize the potential impact of the forest fires on the Horizon facilities and its operations.

In the Slave Lake area of North CentralAlberta, Canadian Natural today performed a controlled shut-in of various properties within the aerial extent of a major forest fire. These properties were producing a daily average of approximately 3,125 barrels of oil and 8 million cubic feet of natural gas. In addition, the pipeline system which transports the production from Canadian Natural's Pelican Lake field will be systematically shut down as tank capacity becomes limited with the Rainbow pipeline system currently not operating due to the forest fires. Although the Pelican Lake field is not in immediate danger of fires at this time, the field storage facilities will be full by May 18, 2011 and if the pipeline cannot be restarted by that time, the Pelican Lake field, which is currently producing approximately 40,000 barrels of oil per day, will have to be shut-in.

Canadian Natural is working with government and policing authorities to ensure its employees and their families are in safe locations. The Company will continue to monitor the extent of the forest fires and will take other proactive measures as necessary to protect its employees, its contractor's employees or its assets.

Canadian Natural is a senior oil and natural gas production company, with continuing operations in its core areas located in Western Canada, the U.K. portion of the North Sea and Offshore Africa.

"It's a precautionary move. Hopefully we can get in there and get a good handle on it.''</p><p>Although she was initially optimistic evacuees would not need to spend the night away from their homes, it was decided later in the evening they would not be allowed back.</p><p>They had the choice of staying at the base camp with firefighters or finding friends or family to bunk with.</p><p>McManus said forest fire officials were diverting resources from the other end of the almost 150-square-kilometre fire to protect the community.</p><p>About 250 firefighters were fighting the blaze, which was burning along both banks of the Athabasca River, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p>Residents of Chisholm had been rousted from their beds Friday night when the fire crept within 400 metres of the community.</p><p>The fire, which is burning south of the hamlet, has destroyed several outbuildings and vehicles, but so far no homes have been lost to flames.</p><p>Meanwhile, Alberta firefighters got some reinforcements Sunday to help them fight about two dozen blazes in the province, including six which were burning out of control.</p><p>About 100 initial attack firefighters arrived from Ontario to help 700 Albertans already on fire lines.</p><p>Fires have already consumed close to 300 square kilometres of Alberta forest and the hot, dry weather that has turned the woods into tinder shows no sign of abating.</p><p>The Ontario reinforcements were requested through the Canadian Inter-agency Forest Fire Centre, but provincial fire officials were waiting to decide where best to deploy them.</p><p>"They'll be posted to areas of greatest need or highest hazard,'' said Kent Ziegler, a provincial fire information officer. "They may go to fires we have currently got on or we may shift them to areas where we may see some fire starts.'' RCMP have still not positively identified the pilot and passenger of a bird-dog spotter plane that crashed while working on another fire near Red Earth Creek.</p><p>Investigation of the crash has been hampered by its proximity to the fire and high winds.</p><p>Norman Brownlee, another fire information officer, said the crash ignited a second smaller fire which was eventually overrun by the larger one.</p><p>"With the wind conditions right now I imagine it could be very difficult to conduct much investigation at the site,'' he said.</p><p>He said the 400-hectare fire, being battled by about 100 firefighters, was listed as being held, but was not yet under control.</p><p>The Airspray (1967) Limited Cessna 310 crashed Friday in a hilly, forested area about 100 kilometres north of Red Earth Creek.</p><p>The aircraft, with a contract pilot and a veteran provincial air attack officer on board, was helping guide water bombers on their runs over the fire.</p><p>Stress teams were helping firefighters cope with the crash and the deaths of their co-workers, said Ziegler.</p><p>"The teams are all quite close and the tragedy has hit them hard, but we're working through it together,'' he said. "And we'll continue to do our job fighting fires as safely as possible.'' urn:contentItem:6GGY-41K3-RRSN-31HS-00000-00Driver ignores forest fire road closure barrier in Kawartha Lakes, impaired charges laid2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Driver ignores forest fire road closure barrier in Kawartha Lakes, impaired charges laidMetroland Staff

A 43-year-old Irondale woman faces impaired charges after a single-vehicle collision on Wednesday.

Kawartha Lakes OPP say on Aug. 13 at about 6:53 p.m., officers were notified of a motor vehicle driving through the road closure barricade on Bury's Green Road.

The barricade was in place due to a forest fire in the Burnt River area. The fire involves 27 hectares of forest and is located west of County Road 49, south of County Road 121 and north of Bury's Green.

OPP say officers located the vehicle and driver after receiving a call and entered into an impaired driving investigation.

"The driver sustained minor injuries from the collision. The driver was arrested and charged with Criminal Code and Highway Traffic Act offences," say OPP.

A 43-year-old Irondale woman was charged with:

Failure or Refusal to Comply with DemandCareless DrivingFail to Report AccidentFail to Remain

The accused is scheduled to appear in the Ontario Court of Justice in Lindsay at a later date. The drivers license was suspended for 90 days and the motor vehicle was impounded for seven days.

(CP) - Forest fires ravaging northwestern Ontario could end up burning a $920-million hole in the province's economy, government foresters said Wednesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire whipping through precious forestland could end up costing the economy that much in lost jobs, taxes and other spinoff effects, says John Huybers of the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>The province could lose up to $92 million alone from the fees it charges companies to cut down Crown land, says Huybers.</p><p>"It's a real, real shame,'' said Huybers, shaking his head, as yet another helicopter whisks away firefighters to one of more than 250 fires in Ontario.</p><p>Foresters base their prediction on the value of land burning and how much has been destroyed so far.</p><p>Fires had destroyed more than 2,210 square kilometres of forestland by Wednesday. Another 2,000-plus square kilometres were ablaze.</p><p>A lot of the land that's been destroyed was traditional hunting and trapping grounds for aboriginals, said Bob Thomas of the Natural Resources Ministry.</p><p>Skies are blanketed in acrid white smoke. A satellite photograph showed the smoke covered almost as much area as Hudson Bay.</p><p>Foresters are watching the woods they spent their life rejuvenating go up in smoke.</p><p>"It's heart wrenching,'' said Gary McKibbon, a forester for Avenor Inc., who's spent the last 15 years carefully cultivating woodlands in the area.</p><p>"I've put my heart and soul into this, everything from planting to aerial seeding, and now it's all being chewed up by fire.''</p><p>His concerns aren't just personal.</p><p>Jobs could be on the line for Avenor's two woodlands operations in Dryden and Thunder Bay, Ont. depending on how much of the crown land it was depending upon gets destroyed, he said.</p><p>He bristles over the prospect folks in southern Ontario might not care about forestland so remote, and removed from urban areas.</p><p>McKibbon insists Ontario taxpayers consider what the fires could end up costing them in the long run.</p><p>If companies aren't paying the provincial goverment stumpage fees for the wood they cut because forestland is destroyed, that means fewer tax dollars are collected to build schools and renovate hospitals, he said.</p><p>"Everybody's got a stake in his, no matter where they live,'' said McKibbon.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WJ6-Y5X1-F103-354D-00000-00Lack of host communities hampering Pikangikum evacuation, chief says2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSLack of host communities hampering Pikangikum evacuation, chief says

Evacuation by land and water of an Indigenous community threatened by a forest fire in northern Ontario has been put on hold because of a lack of places to send the residents, its chief said on Wednesday.

The evacuation of Pikangikum First Nation was now expected to resume on Thursday, as crews battled a fire burning about six kilometres to the southwest.

The Ontario government said it was reaching out to mayors across the province to ask them to host rest of Pikangikum's 3,800 residents.

"There is an urgent need for host communities to provide a safe haven for evacuees during this difficult time," said Brent Ross, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Solicitor General.

Mathew Hoppe, commander of Pikangikum's emergency operations centre in Thunder Bay, Ont., said the recent spell of rain has helped his organization win some time.

"It's looking better than it was a couple days ago, when there was very thick smoke in the community and it had hampered air operations," Hoppe said. "What we're looking at right now is a better situation going forward for the next few days to give us a chance to get ahead of the game."

Smoke inhalation was a serious issue on Tuesday, prompting Environment Canada to issue a special air quality alert, but Hoppe said some of the smoke had lifted, making it easier to airlift residents out of Pikangikum.

Hoppe said Thunder Bay was hosting 600 evacuees in hotels, and was looking at the logistics of taking in more - regardless of whether Pikangikum can find other hosts.

"There's a calmness in the community in terms of recognizing the weather's a bit nicer, but the threat and the challenge we have is working day to day," he said. "We're still planning a full evacuation, maintaining the goal of pulling all of the people out."

At least 72 firefighters were working on the blaze, said Jolanta Kowalski, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Natural Resources.

For several days, residents have been leaving on military flights, boats and buses for communities in northern Ontario.

Pikangikum Chief Amanda Sainnawap said six buses and 10 boats were called off on Wednesday, but the aim was still to airlift 300 people out.

Residents hoping to leave Pikangikum by driving were running out of options.

urn:contentItem:5WHH-RKK1-JDH1-C13G-00000-00Pikangikum faces 2nd fire evacuation2019-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. B1Pikangikum faces 2nd fire evacuationFirst Nation leader says aircraft standing by to move the most vulnerable amid smoke alertThe Canadian Press

For the second time in just over a month, residents of Pikangikum First Nation in northwestern Ontario are being asked to leave due to smoke from nearby wildfires.

Officials in the remote community say vulnerable residents, including the elderly, pregnant women and those with respiratory problems are being flown out, along with their families.

In a series of Facebook posts on Saturday, Chief Amanda Sainnawap said two planes were available at the local airport to move the most vulnerable.

More than 2,000 community members were forced from their homes in late May and early June, with many only returning a few weeks ago.

According to the most recent information from Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, the largest nearby wildfire as of Saturday afternoon was Red Lake 39 at more than 400 square kilometres.

The Department of National Defence said it has responded to a request from the provincial government for help with the evacuation effort.

A department spokesperson said Sunday that 20 Army Rangers and a Hercules aircraft have been assigned to help.

"The CC-130J Hercules aircraft is not expected to fly into the community to facilitate evacuation efforts until provincial authorities confirm they are ready to begin moving residents," Ashley Lemire said.

Meanwhile, the forest fire heading toward Keewaywin First Nation, 140 kilometres northeast of Pikangikum, continues to grow.

The province's Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry said Saturday the fire, dubbed Red Lake 23, had grown more than 100 square kilometres since Friday to a about 720 square kilometres. It was burning just eight kilometres south of the remote Indigenous community.

Half of Keewaywin's roughly 450 residents were flown out to Timmins on Friday, according to former chief Joe Meekis.

The other half were sent to Sioux Lookout, where local officials said the town is at capacity.

Sioux Lookout manager of corporate services Brian MacKinnon says all evacuees are being held at a hotel, and a local restaurant is providing all of the meals.

MacKinnon said the evacuees had settled in and the town was organizing recreational activities for the children.

Environment Canada issued alerts for air quality in Sioux Lookout, Sandy Lake, Red Lake, Pickle Lake, Kenora, Dryden and Fort Frances.

ATHENS, Greece - A large forest fire in Greece that forced the evacuation of two villages overnight on the island of Evia was abating Monday but was not fully controlled yet.

The fire service said four water-dropping planes and another four helicopters were participating in Monday's operations on Evia, just off central Greece. Hundreds of firefighters and soldiers are on the ground trying to tame the fire.

The blaze broke out Sunday and forced the evacuation of two villages, but fire officials say no damage to homes or injuries have been reported.

Greece is particularly vulnerable to forest fires during its hot, dry summers. On July 23, the country's deadliest wildfire in decades killed scores of people in the seaside resort of Mati, northeast of Athens.

On Monday, the fire service raised the death toll from that blaze to 95, after a 63-year-old man succumbed to his injuries in the hospital.

An investigation is underway into the causes of the Mati fire, as well as into whether authorities responded adequately to the emergency.

The handling of the blaze by the government, civil protection, police and fire service officials has been heavily criticized for the absence of any official evacuation effort. It has also been alleged that there was poor communication between the agencies involved, and that traffic police directed motorists into the blaze.

Authorities have warned of a high risk of wildfires Monday in the greater Athens region and Evia.

The Department of National Defence said it has responded to a request from the provincial government for help with the evacuation effort.

A department spokesperson said Sunday that 20 Army Rangers and a Hercules aircraft have been assigned to help.

"The CC-130J Hercules aircraft is not expected to fly into the community to facilitate evacuation efforts until provincial authorities confirm they are ready to begin moving residents," Ashley Lemire said.

Meanwhile, the forest fire heading toward Keewaywin First Nation, 140 kilometres northeast of Pikangikum, continues to grow.

The province's Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry said Saturday the fire, dubbed Red Lake 23, had grown more than 100 square kilometres since Friday to a about 720 square kilometres. It was burning just eight kilometres south of the remote Indigenous community.

Half of Keewaywin's roughly 450 residents were flown out to Timmins on Friday, according to former chief Joe Meekis.

The other half were sent to Sioux Lookout, where local officials said the town is at capacity.

Sioux Lookout manager of corporate services Brian MacKinnon says all evacuees are being held at a hotel, and a local restaurant is providing all of the meals.

MacKinnon said the evacuees had settled in and the town was organizing recreational activities for the children.

Environment Canada issued alerts for air quality in Sioux Lookout, Sandy Lake, Red Lake, Pickle Lake, Kenora, Dryden and Fort Frances.

A37Slave Lake tries to rise from ashesBut some frustrated residents say they're done with town devastated by forest fire last MayChris Purdy The Canadian PressSLAVE LAKE, ALTA.

Ashraf Khan planned on sticking it out.

He was going to rebuild his burned-down house like hundreds of others and continue to make Slave Lake his home.

But he's tired of fighting with his insurance company and waiting for construction to begin on the levelled lot now blanketed with snow.

"My life's a total mess," says Khan, a 15-year resident of the northern Alberta community devastated by a raging forest fire last spring. "I've come to terms with the fact that I have no choice but to move on."

Khan and his wife, Jacintha Ramlall, will be moving with their two children next month to the Calgary bedroom community of Okotoks.

They're not the only ones waving goodbye to Slave Lake. Town officials don't have specific figures, but about 30 families have indicated they're leaving, too.

Five of 18 RCMP officers have also transferred to new detachments since the fire. Staff Sgt. Roberta McKale says some of the officers had already been scheduled to leave and others who lost their homes decided it was easier to start over somewhere else.

Roughly one-third of the community - nearly 400 homes and businesses, including an apartment complex - was reduced to ash and rubble in May when fierce winds whipped a wildfire through the town with little warning. Most residents had minutes to flee.

Other than scrapes and minor burns, no one was injured. But 2,000 were left homeless. The town's new government building, including the library, was lost, as well as two churches and the radio station.

Damage was pegged at $700 million, which insurance adjusters estimate makes it the second-costliest disaster in the country next to the Quebec ice storm of 1998.

Khan says it doesn't matter that his family lost everything in the fire. They're happy to be alive.

He remembers running through his burning house to make sure his loved ones had escaped. His hair was scorching, household items were melting into the floor, windows were shattering and parked cars outside were exploding.

Months later, another "nightmare" with his insurance company began, he says. Construction has started on about 150 new homes and families have moved into two that are finished. But Khan says delays with his insurance mean he can't get a new house until early 2013.

That's too long to wait, he says. The doctor was sleeping at the seniors' lodge in Slave Lake for several months before he recently moved into a mobile home with former neighbours. His wife and children were couch-surfing at friends' homes, then settled temporarily in Edmonton. Khan is travelling back and forth to see them.

Making it even harder is that three other doctors are planning on leaving Slave Lake, although not for fire reasons.

Khan says it was a tough decision to move permanently, but his family needs stability.

The hardest part has been telling his patients.

"There were lots of tears on both our parts," says Khan. "There still is."

Martha Urquhart has been renting a house in Edmonton since the fire and says she's not planning to return to Slave Lake, at least until her 15-year-old son is done school. "I'm not going to be uprooting him again."

There have been visits to the community and her 18-year-old daughter decided to return and live with friends there. Urquhart says it's a great town and she wishes everyone the best in rebuilding.

"There's a lot of really good people in Slave Lake. They already built a community once. There's no reason they can't do it again."

The last of 189 temporary mobile homes was recently hauled into one of three new subdivisions set up to shelter those crowded in with friends or staying in campers. It was a feat to complete the project in six months when many said it would take more than a year, says Mayor Karina Pillay-Kinnee.

Many residents say they are still angry they didn't have enough warning about the fire and that there was no evacuation call.

Adding fuel to their frustration is a recent government announcement that the fire was deliberately set. The RCMP continue to investigate.

urn:contentItem:5WJ6-SY61-JDH1-C05N-00000-00Lack of host communities hampering Pikangikum evacuation, chief says2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSLack of host communities hampering Pikangikum evacuation, chief says

Evacuation by land and water of an Indigenous community threatened by a forest fire in northern Ontario has been put on hold because of a lack of places to send the residents, its chief said on Wednesday.

The evacuation of Pikangikum First Nation was now expected to resume on Thursday, as crews battled a fire burning about six kilometres to the southwest.

The Ontario government said it was reaching out to mayors across the province to ask them to host rest of Pikangikum's 3,800 residents.

"There is an urgent need for host communities to provide a safe haven for evacuees during this difficult time," said Brent Ross, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Solicitor General.

Mathew Hoppe, commander of Pikangikum's emergency operations centre in Thunder Bay, Ont., said the recent spell of rain has helped his organization win some time.

"It's looking better than it was a couple days ago, when there was very thick smoke in the community and it had hampered air operations," Hoppe said. "What we're looking at right now is a better situation going forward for the next few days to give us a chance to get ahead of the game."

Smoke inhalation was a serious issue on Tuesday, prompting Environment Canada to issue a special air quality alert, but Hoppe said some of the smoke had lifted, making it easier to airlift residents out of Pikangikum.

Hoppe said Thunder Bay was hosting 600 evacuees in hotels, and was looking at the logistics of taking in more - regardless of whether Pikangikum can find other hosts.

"There's a calmness in the community in terms of recognizing the weather's a bit nicer, but the threat and the challenge we have is working day to day," he said. "We're still planning a full evacuation, maintaining the goal of pulling all of the people out."

At least 72 firefighters were working on the blaze, said Jolanta Kowalski, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Natural Resources.

For several days, residents have been leaving on military flights, boats and buses for communities in northern Ontario.

Pikangikum Chief Amanda Sainnawap said six buses and 10 boats were called off on Wednesday, but the aim was still to airlift 300 people out.

Residents hoping to leave Pikangikum by driving were running out of options.

urn:contentItem:5TYC-NBY1-F103-352X-00000-00Summers of smoke and fire stoke B.C. tourism fears2018-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisMETROPg. N5Summers of smoke and fire stoke B.C. tourism fearsDan Healing The Canadian Press Continue reading at thestar.com/vancouver

CALGARY-The smoke has cleared after the worst forest fire season in B.C. history but tourism operators fear the reputational damage to their industry will linger far into the future.

Hundreds of wildfires fanned by hot, dry conditions forced the province to declare a state of emergency in British Columbia for the second year in a row. From Aug. 15 to Sept. 7, evacuation orders, closed roads and smoke-filled parks affected thousands of residents and visitors.

"We've run our guiding business for 30 years - in 30 years, we've had three smoky years and two of them were back-to-back, which is not a good sign, right?" said Ian Eakins of family-owned Wells Gray Adventures. "I'm a bit concerned, absolutely. If this is our future, it's a lot tougher game, isn't it?"

The company which offers guided hut-to-hut backcountry hiking trips in the summer for small groups was shut down for three weeks in 2017 when the province closed Wells Gray Provincial Park due to fire danger.

Many tourism businesses have suffered losses from the back-to-back fire seasons but the damage to B.C.'s brand could be just as costly, said Jeremy Stone, an adjunct professor at the University of British Columbia.

"The brand damage, that's the much more difficult one ... You really start to become associated with, 'This is not a place I should be,'" he said.

urn:contentItem:5PCK-DBC1-DY91-K4F3-00000-00Thousands fleeing fire angered by wait2017-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A2Thousands fleeing fire angered by waitMilitary transport planes join effort in northern ManitobaSteve Lambert The Canadian PressWINNIPEG

Many of the 3,700 people fleeing forest fires in northern Manitoba were still waiting to fly south on Thursday, more than 24 hours after they left their homes on a journey complicated by a lack of transportation.

"They're tired. They're frustrated. There's anger," Chief Alex McDougall of Wasagamack First Nation said as he waited with hundreds of others to board one of two military transport planes bound for Winnipeg, more than 500 kilometres to the south.

"Some of us have been sleeping in terminals. Some of us have been sleeping in gymnasiums. There is some food being provided by the local (grocery) stores."

All 2,000 residents of Wasagamack had to leave Tuesday as a large forest fire came within 800 metres of the community. Because there is no airstrip, people took turns piling into boats in small groups for a 20-minute journey across a section of Island Lake to St. Theresa Point.

Smoke from the blaze also forced out people with health problems from the St. Theresa Point and Garden Hill reserves. Small charter planes, that can carry between nine and 45 people, began ferrying people south to Brandon and Winnipeg on Wednesday, but a backlog persisted.

Thursday morning, two Hercules military transport planes, each capable of carrying 100 people, joined the effort. But the large aircraft could only use the airstrip at Garden Hill, McDougall said, so he and others had to take a two-hour trip by barge from St. Theresa Point to Garden Hill.

In Winnipeg, the Canadian Red Cross prepared to welcome the evacuees by turning a 4,300-square-metre hall at the city's convention centre into an emergency shelter. Volunteers, including members of the Bear Clan Patrol - a non-profit that keeps an eye on inner-city streets - were busy setting up more than 1,000 cots, dozens of eating tables and more.

"We're going to have an area where people can get personal services like hygiene products, hygiene kits, health needs, that sort of thing," explained Shawn Feely, regional vice-president for the Canadian Red Cross.

"Then we have the sleep area ... and then we have the eating area and the recreation area. So for little kids, we'll have people running activities."

By early afternoon, there was a long lineup of evacuees to register at the convention centre. Among them was Malcolm Harper, who had spent two nights in transit with his wife and three children, aged 4, 11 and 13 after leaving Wasagamack for St. Theresa Point.

"The first night, they put us in classrooms in the school ... you could hear everybody, kids crying," he said. "It's frustrating, especially on the kids. You've got to keep them together."

The Manitoba government said the forest fire was still about one kilometre from Wasagamack, and crews were working the line closest to the community to prevent it from advancing.

McDougall said from his vantage point in Garden Hill Thursday morning - just before boarding a Hercules - the smoke seemed to be blowing away.

"We have some relief today from the smoke but ... there's still some heavy smoke and fires burning in the area."

urn:contentItem:5XH9-8111-JDH1-C3G1-00000-00'There will be jobs for people' in fossil-fuel-free future, says speaker at Red Deer presentation2019-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWS'There will be jobs for people' in fossil-fuel-free future, says speaker at Red Deer presentation

Gordon Laxer says he wants people to see there is hope in a future free of fossil fuels.

Laxer, an author, political economist, University of Alberta professor emeritus and Parkland Institute founding director, spoke at Red Deer's Welikoklad Centre on Thursday to discuss what's next for Alberta, in regards to the creation of a green new deal.

"We had that incredible flood in 2013 in Calgary and area, the devastating forest fire in Fort McMurray. We are seeing the effects of climate change everywhere - in Alberta, the North and with the seas rising. We have to take it seriously," said Laxer.

"But we have to address it in a way that is going to make life as good or better than it has been. We can see it as an opportunity and not just a threat."

Laxer said "there will be no one left behind, there will be jobs for people.

"I know there are a lot of Albertans who are hurting - there's been a lot of economic devastation here. We have to come up with a plan about how we're going to make a transition that brings Alberta and all regions of Canada along," he said.

Climate change is an urgent issue, said Christopher D'Lima, president of Red Deer's chapter of The Council of Canadians, a social-action agency.

"There's an old saying: 'Climate change doesn't care if you believe in it or not, it's going to happen.' So let's be realistic and take a look at what other alternatives there are, rather than continuing on the same path," said D'Lima.

"I agree, in Alberta especially, that it's a job issue. However, people need to be more aware of new forms of energy - solar energy, wind energy - and new jobs will come as a result of it. It's not job killing."

READ MORE: Climate Change rally marches through downtown Red Deer

D'Lima said it's important to raise awareness of the impact fossil fuels have on the environment.

"There's so much talk surrounding climate change and demonstrations ... so I think it's important people expand their knowledge in regards to what's happening.

"We continue to use carbon and oil resources, but I believe we have to take a look at what's coming next. These fuels aren't going to last forever, so it's important to take a look at the future of energy," he said.

Today's humidity gave firefighters an edge in their<br/>struggle against a stubborn fire in the Crowsnest Pass. But it's<br/>still too soon to celebrate. Hundreds of people from Blairmore<br/>and Hillcrest still can't go home. Hundreds more in nearby<br/>Coleman are now also in trouble. They had a visit from their<br/>premier today. And, as CTV's Jeff Little reports, Ralph Klein<br/>had a firsthand look at the devastation scarring his province.</p><p>JEFF LITTLE [Reporter]: Less than half a kilometre from the<br/>town of Hillcrest, fire is lurking. Rain and cooler temperatures<br/>put a damper on the Lost Creek fire overnight. Firefighters say<br/>conditions are much better than just 24 hours ago. But the<br/>battle is far from over.</p><p>BRYDON WARD [Sustainable Resources Officer]: The winds again<br/>are going to be a problem. They're from the west-southwest at 20<br/>kilometres, gusting to 40 kilometres per hour. It will be some<br/>intense fire action again.</p><p>LITTLE: The fire has forced 2,000 people from their homes and<br/>another 900 remain on evacuation alert. A fire break on the<br/>outskirts of Blairmore has been widened just in case. It is the<br/>last line of defence.<br/></p><p>The fire is now costing the province of Alberta more than one<br/>million dollars a day. Alberta premier Ralph Klein came to see<br/>the damage firsthand, and he was asked about a future aid program<br/>for the community. He says it's too early to talk about that.</p><p>RALPH KLEIN [Alberta Premier]: The thing that has impressed me<br/>most is just the tremendous sense of community and people pulling<br/>together and the coordination of activities.</p><p>LITTLE: Meanwhile, most have left this quiet neighbourhood in<br/>Blairmore. But George and Mabel Wilson have stayed. They won't<br/>leave until they have to go.</p><p>GEORGE WILSON [Blairmore Resident]: Probably go over to the<br/>Legion parking lot. And we've got sleeping bags. And we'll just<br/>sit there until we'd have to leave there. And if you had to<br/>leave there that meant the town was gone.</p><p>LITTLE: About 60 people are now staying at the Crowsnest<br/>Community Centre. And there's no indication when they will get<br/>to go home.</p><p>DALLAS McLEOD [Hillcrest Resident]: It's getting kind of<br/>difficult staying at people's places and stuff like that. I'd<br/>like to get back in the routine.</p><p>LITTLE: While 18,000 hectares of forest have been lost, no<br/>homes have been destroyed. But firefighters say with the<br/>forecast calling for strong wind and temperatures in the<br/>30-degree range, the next 48 hours will be critical.<br/></p><p>Jeff Little, CTV News, in the Crowsnest Pass.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4977-YTY0-00RJ-F4J0-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="442"/><timeReceived>23:00:00 - urn:contentItem:5T9F-7DK1-F103-33P6-00000-00Seguin mayoral hopefuls on protecting the environment2018-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Seguin mayoral hopefuls on protecting the environment

SEGUIN TOWNSHIP - The environment is changing, washing out roadways, decreasing water quality and drying out forests.

With an eye to protect Seguin's environment while supporting housing and business development, the township has been studying waterways, ensuring septic systems are in proper working order, guiding property owners on maintaining a natural shoreline and adjusting its roadway salt use.

With the changing environment and strong storms throughout the year, it increased reserves to handle them and is improving roadways to decrease washouts.

As the municipal election approaches, environmental concerns are moving to the forefront.

"Mayors are sort of the super councillors in term of legislative framework in Ontario, they provide a moral leadership role and can bring an agenda to council, but yes, council as a whole needs to address these issues," said Jim Gray, executive director of Environmental Defence, a non-partisan environmental organization.

The changing environment means townships should, in part, reconsider where development is allowed, review septic design and distance from waterways, set a required depth for wells and support energy-efficient buildings, said Gray.

A current councillor and environmental planner by trade, he said Seguin has to adapt to the new reality.

In the midst of a campaign to elect a new Seguin mayor, the North Star asked candidates Mario Buszynski, Ann MacDiarmid and Mark Stivrins: "How would you, as the mayor, protect Seguin as the 'Natural Place to Be,' given what scientists tell us is an increased rate of environmental change due to humans' impact on the environment?"

"In my role on council, I have already seen Seguin Township adapt to extreme weather events," Buszynski wrote.

He vowed to continue road improvement; a working relationship with the Muskoka Watershed Council, Georgian Bay Biosphere Reserve and other municipalities, and upper level governments for the latest research; and a policy to decrease salt use on winter road and ensuring fire protection.

"The drought this summer has killed a lot of trees and there are many dead branches on the forest floor that could be used as fuel in a forest fire. A small forest fire on the long arm of Otter Lake made the spectre of a raging inferno like Parry Sound 33 is a very real possibility. Owing to some quick action by local cottagers to contain the fire until Seguin arrived, it was extinguished very quickly. The type of forest that will develop over time and the drought-like conditions mean that we all need to be fire smart in terms of our buildings and Seguin needs to be fire ready. Of particular concern are those properties that are water access only."

Ann MacDiarmid, who helped found Safe Quiet Lakes, said if elected "I propose to work very closely with the watershed councils throughout our region and adopt the principles and recommendations that they endorse."

Those include, MacDiarmid continued, strengthening water quality monitoring, reducing road salt and possibly replacing it with alternative products, partnership with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry to protect wetland ecosystems and regular review policies on infrastructure, storm water, firefighting and environmental science.

"In addition, it is vitally important that council support and strengthen our participation in the West Parry Sound Emergency Response Plan .... and the invasive species protocol for species such as the Asian carp, giant hogweed and phragmites all of which trace back to the warming of our world," she wrote.

Mark Stivrins hangs his cap on being a local contractor with first-hand experience building roads and septics.

"I know our roads need to be built with more than just the dollars and cents in mind. During the council meeting where they discussed the fund increase, no member of council asked if standards have been increased," he wrote.

He pledged to work with the MNR to avoid breaking beaver dams washing out roads and the North Bay-Mattawa Conservation Authority and the Ontario Onsite Wastewater Association, "to determine an enhanced water diversion standard for our septics. Floodplains and run-off can have severe impact on our lakes if our septics are not designed with the new reality in mind."

"This is the value of a mayor with direct experience in roads, septics and hard services. These items come with a cost though. We can afford them if we don't waste taxpayer money and resources on further regulation," he said.

Story behind the story

With a changing environment seen in part by the largest fire, by far, for decades in the district, Parry Sound 33, and rainstorms washing out roadways, the North Star decided to reach out to Seguin's mayoral candidates.

urn:contentItem:5SV2-K9N1-DY9S-T0YK-00000-00Storms, dead trees could hinder firefighting near Yosemite2018-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL,TRAVELStorms, dead trees could hinder firefighting near YosemiteStorms, dead trees could hinder firefighting near YosemiteThe Associated Press

MARIPOSA, Calif. - A deadly forest fire kept spreading Wednesday west of Yosemite National Park, and erratic winds and trees killed by a historic California drought are expected to pose more problems for firefighters, officials said.

The blaze between the park and the town of Mariposa that's popular with visitors has scorched 27 square miles (70 square kilometres) of dry brush and timber and is largely burning out of control, said Richard Eagan, a spokesman with the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.

Forecasters expect thunderstorms Thursday afternoon to produce erratic, gusty winds that can be dangerous for more than 1,800 firefighters trying to stop the flames that started Friday. Another concern is thousands of trees killed by a yearslong drought.

"Dead trees are everywhere, north and south of the state, and when you add strong winds that can send ambers flying up to 5 miles (8 kilometres), it can pose a huge risk for firefighters," Eagan said.

The flames have shut down Highway 140, a key route into the park, during tourist season and forced evacuations in nearby communities. But three other park entrances were open, as were trails, campgrounds, restaurants and lodges, though smoke is polluting the air and limiting visibility.

Smoke from the fire about 4 miles (6 kilometres) from the park's west entrance may be heavy at times, and visitors should be prepared to limit heavy outdoor activity when air quality is poor, park officials said.

urn:contentItem:5K48-V4M1-F197-54BS-00000-00Stayner native saved neighbourhood of 85 homes from Fort McMurray fire2016-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Stayner native saved neighbourhood of 85 homes from Fort McMurray fire

Rhemier Reid wasn't letting the Fort McMurray forest fire take his home without a fight.

The Stayner native works for the Municipality of Wood Buffalo as an equipment operator and lives in Gregoire Lake Estates, a community 35 km from Fort McMurray.

When the fire started towards his community, a cul-de-sac of about 85 homes, on May 3, he decided to stay and protect his house and his neighbours' homes.

"The odds were good, that we could give it a good go," he said.

Reid graduated from Collingwood Collegiate Institute, studied firefighting at Texas A&M University and was a volunteer with the Clearview Fire Department for about eight years.

"I understand fire more than a lot of the residents here," he said. "I got a lot of good common sense and experience from Clearview."

Reid said he filled abandoned cisterns with water from the lake and backyard pools to soak down homes and lawns.

"If a forest fire starts ripping thorough, start pre-soaking your lawn and your house," he said. "I don't know (what) the outcome (would have been) if we didn't pre-soak. We soaked all the roofs, we soaked all the lawns in the days prior so when the fire was close enough to spit embers, we didn't have any issues."

He said the fire was surrounding him and was within 100 feet. However, because a lake was nearby, he was confident he could battle the fire.

Reid said fighting fires in Clearview gave him the confidence to and "resourcefulness," to stand pat.

"I learned the fundamentals of firefighting," he said. "We're always, for a big farm fire, we're always drafting water. I was confident ... 99 per cent ... we could make a stop on it."

Reid slept on his deck to keep an eye on the fire made sure he had an exit strategy.

"Jump in the lake," he said.

If the fire got too close, he was set to jump in a canoe and paddle away.

While watching the expansive fire burn so close, Reid gained a new understanding of the power of forest fires.

"We had fire everywhere and embers," he said. "Trees were popping up (in flames) every where. It made you respect the fire. I've never seen anything like this."

There are 85 homes in his neighbourhood and not one was lost to fire.

What a difference a little bit of cooler weather and lower humidity makes.

The Meachen Creek fire is now classified as 'being held' rather than 'out of control'.

That means the fire is not likely to spread beyond predetermined boundaries with the current resources assigned to it and the current weather forecast.

As such the RDEK is lifting the evacuation alert for the 65 properties in Electoral Area E in the St. Mary Valley as of noon Monday, September 10, 2018, on the recommendation of the Incident Commander.

According to the latest update from Wildfire BC, containment lines have continued to hold on the east side and there has been no further encroachment towards the St. Mary Lake community. The Meachen Creek fire is now 70 per cent contained. Today's objectives will be much the same as yesterday. Crews will continue establishing hose lines around the excursion and continue to work in the Fiddler Creek drainage and Meachen Creek drainage. Bucketing helicopters will be used to support the suppression efforts. Crews will work the spine in the northeast corner and bucket hot spots as required. Removal of structural protection equipment has been completed.

Forestry have re-opened The Gray Creek Pass and Trans Canada Trail from Kimberley to Kootenay Lake, reports Tom Lymbery from Gray Creek

The access was closed August 12th because of forest fire dangers - especially the Meachen Creek fire complex.

"This back country road brings travellers from all over to Kimberley - a Toronto couple with large tire cycles were most disappointed when they checked in Gray Creek just after the closure, as they had come all the way from Toronto especially to ride the Pass," Lymberry said.

The Meachen Creek Forest Service Road at its junction with the Hellroaring FSR remains closed.

And remaining animals use these areas for refuge.</p><p>But not all forest dwellers survive a wildfire.</p><p>Some will die, trapped by flames or overcome by smoke. They're usually smaller animals, like mice and rabbits, which don't move as fast but reproduce quickly.</p><p>And some larger animals will also inevitably die, says Paul Woodard, a fire scientist at the University of Alberta.</p><p>"Man is the most sophisticated animal we know, and even he dies in fires.''</p><p>Woodard says fire creates winners and losers in the animal kingdom.</p><p>"Hawks, owls, bats, woodpeckers, they're winners,'' he says. They feed off the insects that are drawn to dead wood.</p><p>But Martens that climb trees to escape the fire pay the price. And squirrels also lose since the trees are gone.</p><p>Moose, deer, bear, beaver and bison win because they eat the lush new growth that springs up soon after the fire, adds Wein.</p><p>Before Europeans arrived, Aboriginal people often intentionally burned areas of the forest to attract such animals, he says.</p><p>Dave Ealey of Alberta's Environment Department says the effects of forest fires on wildlife populations have been widely studied.</p><p>"That's why we're fairly confident the population will be able to handle it.''</p><p>Wein says the most amazing part of the forest fire is the aftermath - the transformation that takes place in the ecosystem.</p><p>"When you get fire moving through an area, it's an incredible disruption of a system. It's a reorganization, very rapidly, over days and hours and weeks for these animals to find new conditions for themselves.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5WYV-WPW1-F103-333R-00000-00How some Fort McMurray residents are learning to live with bears in the neighbourhood2019-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisEDMONTONPg. 0How some Fort McMurray residents are learning to live with bears in the neighbourhoodHamdi Issawi

EDMONTON-At about 8 a.m. on Aug. 19, Fort McMurray resident Sara Kenney was on her way to work when she found a juvenile black bear rooting through her neighbour's trash.

Living along the edge of a greenbelt in the Thickwood Heights community, Kenney said that was her sixth sighting this year, but from the tone of her voice, one would have been more than enough.

"Yeah, they're all over the place," she said with a sigh over the phone. "The amount of bears I've seen alone this year is insane."

About a week before that, Kenney recalled, she was driving up to Abasand Heights, an area roughly 10 kilometres east of her home, to pick up her 3-year-old son from daycare.

Along the way, she saw a man on a bike shaking a can of bear mace, who started shouting at her to blare her horn at a bear approaching the cyclist from the other side of the street.

"He kept yelling at me to honk and honk and honk, so I kept honking, but the bear didn't really do much," she said. "He still had a ways to go, but he definitely had the man in his sights. They don't seem to fear us as much as they used to."

She had to yell at the bear from the safety of her car before it took off into the woods.

As of Aug. 23, Alberta Fish and Wildlife's enforcement department reported that there have been 164 bear incidents in the Wood Buffalo area this year, with 32 animals relocated and 18 destroyed.

That's not the highest number of incidents the area has seen. Looking back to 2009, the department's records list 530 incidents in 2011, and 285 the year before.

Compared to the rest of the province, where the department has recorded 297 incidents this year, Wood Buffalo seems to have more than its fair share of bears.

After five years living in the neighbourhood, Kenney has come to accept the animals as a fact of life in her neck of the woods, and noted that residents are hesitant to report animals spotted on their block.

"On our street, we're pretty used to it," Kenney said. "A lot of our neighbours don't like to call because we know they can be destroyed, so we just kind of live with it - as horrible as that sounds - but we don't want to see them get shot."

According to Alberta Justice and Solicitor General, which oversees the Fish and Wildlife enforcement department, the rapid expansion and development of urban areas into what was natural animal habitat have made wildlife sightings more common, especially bears in the spring and fall, when the animals are looking to take advantage of unnatural food sources, such as garbage, and bulk up.

"This is due to the fact they are either just exiting hibernation or about to enter it," explained Katherine Thompson, a spokesperson for the ministry, "and the availability of natural food sources are limited."

Colleen Cassady St. Clair, a professor of biological sciences at the University of Alberta, studies human-wildlife interactions, and characterizes the bears' emboldened August activity as a "crazed search for food" necessary to store enough fat to survive the coming winter sleep.

"So for things that bears would be shy around at other times of the year, they just throw caution to the wind," St. Clair said, "and any source of food attracts them."

However, she noted, carnivores such as wolves, cougars and black bears have generally increased their range and numbers across North America.

In northern Alberta, St. Clair explained, agriculture, forestry and oil and gas industries have been carving up forests, creating more open and edge habitat better suited for bears. But also, she said, there has been a shift in wildlife management practices over the past couple of decades.

"Wildlife managers are actively encouraging more coexistence with carnivores," St. Clair said. "So, 20 years ago, they wouldn't have tolerated even the occurrence of a bear near a townsite, whereas now, they begin trying to tolerate that using other tools."

Specifically, she added, tools like public education and aversive conditioning, or "hazing," are replacing lethal management by getting residents to make their homes bear-safe, and conditioning bears to stay away from populated centres so they don't get too comfortable around humans.

While many recognize bear-proof garbage bins as one of the first lines of defence, St. Clair said since bears can smell trash from kilometres away, berries and birdseed are also powerful attractants, along with petroleum products.

Kim Titchener, founder and owner of Bear Safety & More, works with government agencies, industries and communities to reduce conflicts between bears and people. Besides running education workshops, that involves conducting risk assessments for oil and gas companies, and flagging attractants like exposed jerry cans, small spills and barrels of diesel left out in the open.

"The bears are walking around and looking for things, and if they find something like this, it's like a cologne," she said. "They'll knock it over and rub it all over their body - it's truly amazing the mess that can be created."

But what also makes Fort McMurray unique, Titchener noted, was the wildfire that devastated the community in 2016, making the area an ideal bear habitat, especially in the middle of berry season.

"When we're talking about a community that's been through a massive forest fire, you're going to have a lot of really good bear foods between three to five years afterwards," she added. "Even the first year after the forest fire, we started to see a lot of green-up - so a lot of really good bear habitat has been created in the Wood Buffalo region because of that forest fire."

That's means residents in bear country may need to go as far as removing berry bushes and fruit trees from their properties if they hope to keep bears away, Titchener said.

In Fort McMurray's Abasand Heights neighbourhood, which several residents flagged as a hot spot for bear sightings, Randy Stefanizyn is no stranger to encounters with the area's wild side. He has also heard chatter from neighbours pegging 2019 as unusually active for bear sightings. Having lived in the area for more than 30 years, he still takes bear safety seriously and exercises caution, but doesn't feel the need to uproot the attractants in his yard.

"My wife has a beautiful garden with sweet peas growing up against the fence," he said, recalling one memorable bear interaction. "We were sitting on the back deck and a bear stood up against the fence, saw us, and just continued to eat the flowers."

That, he added with a chuckle, "is cohabitating at its best."

Most recently, on the afternoon of Aug. 28, a rustling in the trees and bushes behind his house gave way to a mother bear and her three cubs, which proceeded to roam around the couple's yard on a hunt for food.

"They're roly poly, and she's watching out for them, always on high alert," he said.

Stefanizyn and his wife were safe in their house, he said, but a face-to-face encounter like that is one that would scare even the most savvy bear specialist.

"When you're living in the boreal forest, these are the kinds of things that you're going to experience," he said. "You just have to respect the animal, give them a wide berth, and normally, there's been no issues."

That's not to say he takes a laissez-faire approach to bear safety on his block. He's still keen on keeping his garbage cans secure, and only hauling them out for scheduled pickups.

An avid hiker, who also lives on a greenbelt, he knows to leave home with a can of bear spray and bells to ward off wildlife on a trek. And when there is a bear sighting, he's sure to post a notice on the Facebook group so his neighbours are forewarned, secure their pets, or stay indoors to avoid risky situations.

Co-operation and co-ordination on a community level, St. Clair flagged, is also an effective way to reduce interactions between bears and people, by keeping all parties considered out of harm's way.

"Living in a community where, not just one's own yard but the whole community participates in controlling attractants - that can really reduce conflict, too," she said. "That kind of positions the public to be partners in the responsibility of keeping bears alive and people safe."

For Kenney's part, as a mother of three, preparation isn't an option. She has bear spray, bells and bangers positioned at strategic points around her yard and home and "everything short of a shotgun" to help keep her family safe. But she would like to see more people in her community being a little more diligent.

"We are prepared, but other people seem to be really blinded by the beauty of the bears," she said. "I find too many people at the park without bear spray ... I'm telling you right now, you cannot hear them when they're right behind you."

urn:contentItem:5T9N-86C1-JDH1-C39K-00000-00Seguin mayoral hopefuls on protecting the environment2018-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Seguin mayoral hopefuls on protecting the environment

SEGUIN TOWNSHIP - The environment is changing, washing out roadways, decreasing water quality and drying out forests.

With an eye to protect Seguin's environment while supporting housing and business development, the township has been studying waterways, ensuring septic systems are in proper working order, guiding property owners on maintaining a natural shoreline and adjusting its roadway salt use.

With the changing environment and strong storms throughout the year, it increased reserves to handle them and is improving roadways to decrease washouts.

As the municipal election approaches, environmental concerns are moving to the forefront.

"Mayors are sort of the super councillors in term of legislative framework in Ontario, they provide a moral leadership role and can bring an agenda to council, but yes, council as a whole needs to address these issues," said Jim Gray, executive director of Environmental Defence, a non-partisan environmental organization.

The changing environment means townships should, in part, reconsider where development is allowed, review septic design and distance from waterways, set a required depth for wells and support energy-efficient buildings, said Gray.

A current councillor and environmental planner by trade, he said Seguin has to adapt to the new reality.

In the midst of a campaign to elect a new Seguin mayor, the North Star asked candidates Mario Buszynski, Ann MacDiarmid and Mark Stivrins: "How would you, as the mayor, protect Seguin as the 'Natural Place to Be,' given what scientists tell us is an increased rate of environmental change due to humans' impact on the environment?"

"In my role on council, I have already seen Seguin Township adapt to extreme weather events," Buszynski wrote.

He vowed to continue road improvement; a working relationship with the Muskoka Watershed Council, Georgian Bay Biosphere Reserve and other municipalities, and upper level governments for the latest research; and a policy to decrease salt use on winter road and ensuring fire protection.

"The drought this summer has killed a lot of trees and there are many dead branches on the forest floor that could be used as fuel in a forest fire. A small forest fire on the long arm of Otter Lake made the spectre of a raging inferno like Parry Sound 33 is a very real possibility. Owing to some quick action by local cottagers to contain the fire until Seguin arrived, it was extinguished very quickly. The type of forest that will develop over time and the drought-like conditions mean that we all need to be fire smart in terms of our buildings and Seguin needs to be fire ready. Of particular concern are those properties that are water access only."

Ann MacDiarmid, who helped found Safe Quiet Lakes, said if elected "I propose to work very closely with the watershed councils throughout our region and adopt the principles and recommendations that they endorse."

Those include, MacDiarmid continued, strengthening water quality monitoring, reducing road salt and possibly replacing it with alternative products, partnership with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry to protect wetland ecosystems and regular review policies on infrastructure, storm water, firefighting and environmental science.

"In addition, it is vitally important that council support and strengthen our participation in the West Parry Sound Emergency Response Plan .... and the invasive species protocol for species such as the Asian carp, giant hogweed and phragmites all of which trace back to the warming of our world," she wrote.

Mark Stivrins hangs his cap on being a local contractor with first-hand experience building roads and septics.

"I know our roads need to be built with more than just the dollars and cents in mind. During the council meeting where they discussed the fund increase, no member of council asked if standards have been increased," he wrote.

He pledged to work with the MNR to avoid breaking beaver dams washing out roads and the North Bay-Mattawa Conservation Authority and the Ontario Onsite Wastewater Association, "to determine an enhanced water diversion standard for our septics. Floodplains and run-off can have severe impact on our lakes if our septics are not designed with the new reality in mind."

"This is the value of a mayor with direct experience in roads, septics and hard services. These items come with a cost though. We can afford them if we don't waste taxpayer money and resources on further regulation," he said.

urn:contentItem:5SSH-6GW1-JDH3-G3C3-00000-00Brush fire in Whitestone 'not under control'2018-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:02:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Brush fire in Whitestone 'not under control'

WHITESTONE TWP. - Water bombers and provincial forest firefighters were at work this weekend battling a brush fire near Ardbeg.

As of Monday morning the 5-hectare fire remained not under control as West Parry Sound's fire rating remains at 'extreme'.

The Whitestone Fire Department was called to the brush fire along the CN Tracks at the Bunny Trail Friday night and called in the Ministry of Natural Resources due to its size. On Sunday, the province had three planes and two ground crews fighting the fire which was 5 hectares large.

According to the province's forest fire website, this is just one of 504 in the northern half of the province this summer, compared to 143 in 2017; the 10-year average is 360.

During an 'extreme' fire rating camp fires are prohibited in all seven townships, as are fireworks in Archipelago, Carling, McDougall, McKellar and Whitestone.

The decision to go from a rating of 'high' to 'extreme' the morning of Thursday, July 5 takes into account the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry's fire rating, fires in the northeast of the province and the hot weather.

The 'extreme' fire rating in West Parry Sound is expected to last into this week, said McDougall Fire Chief Brian Leduc Thursday.

"Don't take chances, don't burn, don't light fireworks; if someone starts a fire they are financially responsible for the suppression costs of that fire," he said.

In Whitetone, four tickets for lighting a campfire during the ban were handed out as of Monday morning.

A3Forest fire evacuees could soon return home Province, First Nations communities developing plan based on safetyThe Canadian Press

People evacuated from northwestern Ontario communities because of forest fires could begin returning home soon, provincial government officials said Sunday.

The government is working on a plan that would allow those affected by the fires to go back to their communities, said Deputy Minister of Community Safety Ian Davidson.

"That will be based on personal safety and developing a plan with individual First Nations, but we're working on that right now," he said.

Davidson did not give a timetable for the return but said "it could happen relatively quickly."

Asked about the situation, Premier Dalton McGuinty said "the fire does appear at this point in time to be less threatening than in past days.

"We're working now to take care of families that have been displaced, and when it's safe to do so we'll help them get back home," McGuinty said.

Almost 3,600 people have been removed from communities since evacuations began June 21. Many of them have been moved to regional centres such as London and Thunder Bay.

Three First Nations communities have been fully evacuated while another six have been partially evacuated.

Davidson said there are no further evacuations planned at this time.

Government officials will decide who will get to return home first based on the safety of their destinations and the capacity of the government to move them, he said.

There were 10 new fires as of 6 p.m. Saturday, said Norma Griffin, the spokesperson for the provincial Ministry of Natural Resources. That brings the total number of active fires to 118, and more were expected to be added Sunday.

The weather forecast this week looks favourable, said Griffin, but firefighters will need more rain to help them put out the fires.

Over the weekend, government officials were able to reunite families who had been separated during the evacuations, Davidson said.

They found five individuals who had been separated from their families, he said.

They resolved two of those cases on Saturday, two more were to be resolved on Sunday and they were still working on the other case.

Nishnawke Aski Nation Grand Chief Stan Beardy told CBC News on Saturday that parents had been separated from their children during evacuations.

(CP) - The Ontario government has inched closer toward the privatization of fighting forest fires, hiring part-time workers trained by six companies.</p><p>The Ministry of Natural Resources said it hopes to cut costs by awarding contracts to companies who will be called on short notice to pitch in with Ministry crews during escalating emergencies.</p><p>Crews will be trained by Wikwemikong Development Corp. in Wikwemikong, Outland Reforestation in Toronto, Lake Superior First Nation in Thunder Bay, Geraldton Community Forest in Geraldton, Matagami First Nation in Gogama and Whitefish Lake First Nation in Naughton.</p><p>The new crews will make the firefighting system more efficient and reduce transportation costs incurred by bringing in extra fire crews from outside the province, said Natural Resources Minister Chris Hodgson.</p><p>The privately trained fire crews will only be used for sustained attack and won't be called on for initial response to forest fires, said Barry McKnight.</p><p>There were 23 new fires reported in the province from Friday to Sunday, most of them in nortwestern Ontario.</p><p>Firefighters were working to control 15 fires covering 600 hectares, the Provincial Fire Centre reported Monday. Four waterbombers - two from Quebec and two from the Northwest Territories - were called in to help.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata OMAR SACHEDINA: Thousands of people are stranded along the coast of southern Australia tonight as wildfires race towards them and roads are shut. There is an eerie glow in state of Victoria where people have been urged to put on lifejackets and run to the shore. More than 100 fires are still burning in New South Wales and Queensland. And as temperatures across the country soar to 40 degrees, there is word tonight of more Canadian reinforcements. CTV's John Vennavally-Rao has the latest.

JOHN VENNAVALLY-RAO (Reporter): The Aussie assault on the fast moving flames has come from both above and below, with new images showing what firefighters down under have been up against. And tonight a group of 14 Canadian firefighters are bound for Australia where they'll join the more than 50 Canadian wildfire specialists already in the country.

STEPHEN TULLE (Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre): The conditions they're experiencing and witnessing are extreme. It's conditions they've not experienced in their careers.

VENNAVALLY-RAO: Conditions that have prompted emergency warnings across the state of Victoria.

ANDREW CRISP (Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner): This is a high risk day for Victoria. This is a day we do not often see. State is dry, it is going to be very hot, it is going to be very, very windy.

VENNAVALLY-RAO: In the region of East Gippsland, tens of thousands of residents and tourists have been urged to evacuate on Sunday. But as fires approach, today officials closed the main road in and out, trapping some of those who did not heed the warnings.

LISA NEVILLE (Australian Police and Emergency Services Minister): It's too dangerous to be driving, not only just from smoke, but because of the erratic nature and the fast moving nature of these fires.

VENNAVALLY-RAO: Over the last few months, Australia has been gripped by record breaking heat and dry conditions, fuelling hundreds of fires. So far more than a thousand homes have been destroyed, and just today another volunteer firefighter died, the third killed this month. As for residents who've left their homes, some are now living in campsites.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: Evacuated here so that we were all safe for the night and see how it all pans out I guess.

VENNAVALLY-RAO: In Sydney, though, the fireworks are still being prepared for new year's eve, despite calls for them to be cancelled. To the west, though, a major new year's eve music festival has been shut down, and 9,000 festivalgoers told to pack up and go home.

JESSICA DUCROU (Falls Festival Co-Producer): We took advice from all of the stakeholders who are experts in their area, and we just couldn't proceed with the festival.

VENNAVALLY-RAO: Later this week, even more Canadian firefighters will head for Australia, bringing the total there to 86. Omar.

SACHEDINA: Helping out at a time of great need. All right, John, thanks.
